newsitem.title: GERMANY: Mercedes faces crunch time with A-class.
newsitem.headline: Mercedes faces crunch time with A-class.

text.p: It's crunch time for Mercedes-Benz AG, whose cars have long been a symbol of the upper crust establishment, as it now seeks a new type of buyer -- youthful consumers with an anti-establishment streak.

The German luxury carmaker on Tuesday will roll out its new A-class compact car, a bid to lure customers at a younger age into the Mercedes brand and also to help expand the carmaker's sales to one million vehicles by the turn of the century.

Mercedes knows very well it must revamp its image to attract buyers for the A-class -- aimed at 30-something singles, two-person households and hip young families -- in a difficult sales environment for the Stuttgart-based group.
"It's certainly unconventional for Mercedes but the advertising strategy for this car has been unconventional and unique from the start," said Mercedes spokesman Roland Klein.

But the question still remains -- can Mercedes attract fickle young buyers to its product line with a car, which has strong fans among the automotive press for its design and safety features, that costs less than half its other models?

"It doesn't seem to be the Mercedes we know and love," said Peter Schmidt at consultant group Automotive Industry Data in England. "The car is a completely different animal than the rest of the Mercedes product range."
"It is still to be debated whether the A-class is too much a move for Mercedes from one extreme to the other and whether it will alienate loyal but older customers," Schmidt said.

Mercedes' efforts, which have included millions of marks for marketing campaigns to build up a potential customer base of more than 300,000 names -- of which 100,000 are considered by Mercedes to be "hot prospects" -- have been rather striking.

An 18-metre high "cosmic" cube will be built on Frankfurt's famous Opernplatz for Tuesday's gala event to formally unveil the car, which was also shown at the Geneva car show in March, and begin a traveling road show around Germany and Europe.

Members of the Catalan theatre company La Fura dels Baus, ("The Rats from the Sewer") and best known for "terrorising" audiences at a 1989 Sydney performance with chainsaws, shopping trolleys and offal, will be on hand at the Frankfurt event.

At the Geneva car show, stomping dancers unveiled the car as part of a fevered-pitch routine that included some using the car, to be priced at about 30,000 marks, as a percussion instrument in front of Daimler boss Juergen Schneider.

People responding to Mercedes' advertising campaign have also received a glitzy brochure with 20-something models reminiscent of a hip fashion catalogue that folds out to 3.6 meters long -- the same length as the compact vehicle.

The events have been a far cry from past gala openings at which champagne and appetizers were in good supply as Mercedes fought for well-heeled customers against rivals BMW AG and Audi, a unit of major carmaker Volkswagen AG.
Now Mercedes, which spent $1.65 billion to design the A-class, also faces a tough fight from VW and General Motors Corp in a mass-market bid to broaden its luxury appeal.

Some experts wonder whether the A-class may be too much a departure from the existing Mercedes line, noting BMW and Audi have lower-end models that blend in well with existing product lines and do a good job of attracting buyers and keeping them.

"People that opt to buy the A-class are a different class of people," said Bob Barber, an industry analyst at HSBC James Capel in London. "They are not buying it necessarily because of the Mercedes label, which carries a pricing premium."

The car at first, anyway, will be viewed as a success by Mercedes due to the anticipated heavy demand for the vehicle, expcted to have annual sales of about 200,000 units, when it starts reaching customers in the coming months.
"The first 12 months will look great, then we will see how demand works out," Barber said.
